Hi Shane, 

Well there is already one application of NEAT to a game, Neuro-=

Evolving Robotic Operatives (NERO). For this game a real-time version 
of =
NEAT was created and the player essentially trains a team of robots 
to fig=
ht. Then makes battles with some other player's team. It is fun, 
it is eve=
n an entirely new genre of computer games. 

But I guess you mean games of =
a broader range, where the player 
competes with, or fights the NPCs, rathe=
r than training them. If we 
cut out the FPS genre, there are many other ge=
nres where NEAT can be 
applied. One example is strategic games, where the =
units are like in 
NERO but play against yours and get smarter as the game =
progresses. 
Generally, in cases where the NPCs are many and of the same ty=
pe, they 
don't have to be as intelligent as NPCs in FPS games, where you f=
ight 
a bot directly, not lots of them. In cases where one population of 
e=
volving NPCs plays against another, an interesting co-evolutionary 
arms ra=
ce may occur. 

It is important to note that NPCs playing against the playe=
r may just 
become *too good* at their task and therefore make the game bor=
ing. In 
order to keep the game interesting, Novelty Search can be applied,=
 but 
there is an issue. NS will have to explore too ugly and stupid 
behav=
iors before it ever finds a meaningful one. Therefore it is not 
suited to =
real-time video games where the agents learn as the game 
progresses. I'd l=
ike to see if there is something proving me wrong 
about it. 

Now about em=
otions. Modeling emotions through NE sounds like 
supervised training to me=
. Observing emotions and learning to imitate 
them and make up its own. The=
re are games so close to reality that 
will have to include realistic emoti=
ons for the next-generation NPCs. 
Such games are "Grand Theft Auto" and "T=
he Sims". 

If emotions are not to be evolved, but scripted, NEAT can poten=
tially 
use the emotions as inputs for possible intelligent behaviors. Play=
ers 
can produce their own character behaviors through interactive 
evoluti=
on or just pick up and download behaviors from an archive 
generated by Nov=
elty Search. 

Borrowing some ideas from chat-bots that simulate emotion ma=
ybe is a 
good thing to start. I have a book in bulgarian (back from 1974),=
 
where it is mentioned about one model proposed by the Ukraine 
scientist =
Nikolay Amosov. Here is a cite from it (my translation, 
sorry about any er=
rors):

/*** CITATION ***/ 
...

Excellent results were obtained from the i=
mplementation of the 
proposed model for AI by the soviet scientist Nikolay=
 Amosov. Before 
we tell you about his concept, let's introduce the termino=
logy. Amosov 
thinks, that "Thinking - this is processing information. The =

information can be considered as facts for the object/s, represented 
by a=
 *model*. The model is a complex system that reflects another 
complex syst=
em - the object/s. Therefore the act of thinking is a 
manipulation with th=
e models from the inner and outside world, 
targeted to achieve certain goa=
ls. A system with this capability can 
be called *intelligence*."

... 

Th=
e human brain is a very complex system, made up from billions of 
neurons w=
ith differing characteristics. Via many connections, they 
connect into a h=
uge network. In this network the models of the inner 
and outer reality are=
 created. In this sense, the model is a group of 
interconnected neurons th=
at excite together. 

... 

The processing of the information happens via a=
ctivating the neurons 
and sending impulses between them. That way the mode=
ls are activated 
and interact. The impulses come from the inner and outer =
worlds (by  
events that are sensed) and activate the apropriate models. Fo=
r 
example the smell of burning wood excites the model that represents 
fir=
e and makes us search for the source of fire. The sense of hunger 
excites =
the model of the meal we wish to eat and makes us imagine the 
food and the=
 ways we can get it. *(The absence of addictive drugs have 
similar effects=
 - Peter C.)*. 

The models that get excited in our brain simultaneously ar=
e too many, 
because the environmental challenges are too many as well. Her=
e is why 
a mechanism is needed, a system, that chooses only one model from=
 the 
set and excites it, putting it into the focus of our attention, while=
 
inhibiting the others. According to Amosov, and this is the heart of 
his=
 concept, this task is performed by a core system, the System of 
Excitemen=
t and Inhibition (SEI). Its task is to coordinate the 
interaction between =
models. SEI does not work all the time, but on 
short impulses. It excites =
the model that has the highest level of 
activity, but periodically turns o=
ff in order to "listen" for other 
models that became active. Because the e=
nvironment and the inner state 
are constantly changing, the models are cha=
nging as well.

...

We cannot take a deeper look at all models now, becaus=
e they are too 
many, but according to Amosov, creativity can be viewed as =
the 
creation of new models based on existing others. We also need to 
unde=
rline the big role of emotions. They are the main engine of SEI. 
The activ=
ity of the System of Excitement and Inhibition correlates 
directly to the =
activity of emotions. 

/*** END OF CITATION ***/

OK well this citation sh=
ould bring up some ideas of what can be done. 
In fact it has to be already=
 implemented somewhere, I don't know where 
though, maybe as a paper or tap=
e on the first computers :) It is 
written that when SEI is turned on, the =
experimental bot exhibits very 
intelligent behavior. And very "emotional" =
also. If SEI is off, the 
models are like fighting each other and the bot g=
ets confused. It is 
just one interesting model for an emotional AI, I don'=
t know if it has 
been well-researched, but it seems like a good thing to t=
ry and get 
implemented. This is my opinion concerning emotional AIs. 

Oth=
erwise there are many many games where the NPCs can use NEAT, at 
least par=
tially in order to modify their strategies. The most 
promising technique I=
 know of is Knowledge-Based NEAT ( KB NEAT, http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~nn/pr=
oject-view.php?ProjID=3D131 ). You can 
script a general FSM-based AI and t=
hen convert it to a working neural 
network with the same behavior. Then yo=
u can leave it to improve 
further, complexifying and possibly altering the=
 strategy through 
rtNEAT. This is basically injecting a priori information=
 for the 
search, a good kick-start for evolution, which is much better tha=
n 
searching for it from scratch. Plus, it is guaranteed that the whole 
kn=
owledge is there, because they are not evolved from some weird 
lower-dimen=
tional spaces, initially progressing quickly but turning 
out to be dead-en=
ds for further progress in the long run. 

It is also possible to exploit g=
eometric relationships in the task 
domain via Connective CPPNs (HyperNEAT)=
. My NEVH project is one 
example, though it didn't ever achieve perfect wa=
lking in a 3D 
simulated physics environment. My conclusion about it is tha=
t gravity 
makes the humanoid model fall too soon and FS cannot progress. E=
ven NS 
cannot progress in the way I want, unless the behavior 
characteriz=
ation is changed and the gravity removed. But for other 
animal-like robot =
morphologies it should apply perfectly. 
It is actually not just about walk=
ing gaits. Any game has geometric 
regularities that HyperNEAT can discover=
 and exploit. 

Peter C
